import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

source.dabe914b: ### Superspreaders from the XIX Century: Bohemians and their Lifestyle, Superspreaders from the XXI: Pubs, Restaurants and Parties Anything similar in that behavior?
source.8f1c2215: #Covid-19 as a Multifactorial Disease Dependant on human behavior to be controlled. Not a task for Snippers. Or even Amateurs. Require many well-succeeded approaches. Actions involve the whole Planet. No Vulnerable should be let behind. Covid-19 is a multifactorial disease and is highly dependant on human behavior to be spread/controlled. It's Not a task for Snippers. Not for Amateurs. Dealing with it require many well-succeeded approaches. Actions demand the whole World participation. And must include those in vulnerable situations. Otherwise, will be another TB. For those that are reading this Kaggle Notebook don't expect any ML improvement. It's just like culture/literature/musicians/artists had made before with other diseases. e.g.: ### Contagious Songs and Diseases Tuberculosis AKA Consumption. La Dame aux Camélias (TB or Syphilis?) La Dame aux Camélias by Alexandre Dumas fils, Some believe that the fictional Marguerite's illness cause of death, "consumption", was a 19th-century euphemism for syphilis, as opposed to the more common meaning of tuberculosis. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Dame_aux_Cam%C3%A9lias La Traviata (TB?) La traviata by Giuseppe Verdi where Violetta a young woman dying of consumption (Again!) After a series of severe coughs and almost fainting, Violetta begins to feel dizzy. Probably, she had TB. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_traviata La Bohème (TB?) La bohème is an opera in four acts, composed by Giacomo Puccini between 1893 and 1895, based on Scènes de la vie de bohème (1851) by Henri Murger. The story is set in Paris around 1830, and shows the Bohemian lifestyle (known in French as "la bohème") of a poor seamstress and her artist friends. Mimi is slowly being consumed by a deadly illness (most likely TUBERCULOSIS, known by the catchall name "consumption" in the nineteenth century). Rodolfo, in his poverty, can do little to help Mimì. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_boh%C3%A8me Rent (HIV) Rent a rock musical with music, lyrics, and book by Jonathan Larson, based on Giacomo Puccini's 1896 opera La Bohème. It tells the story of a group of impoverished young artists struggling to survive and create a life in Lower Manhattan's East Village in the thriving days of bohemian Alphabet City, under the shadow of HIV/AIDS. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rent_(musical) Only artists can sing while people are dying of some serius disease? Analysing the stories above, seems that a BOHEMIAN LIFESTYLE plus POVERTY are both components that contributes to their dramatic deaths. Only artists can sing while people are dying of some serius disease like TB, HIV and trust me, it's just a question of time to have a musical about Covid.

source.2b969cf8:
The director-general of the World Health Organization (WHO), Tedros Adhanom, said that a vaccine against covid-19 is urgently needed, but stressed that an immunizer alone will not solve all the vulnerabilities of the global crisis. 

<font color="#EC7063">Essential Public Health and an Approach that Encompasses Humans, Animals and the Planet.</font>

"A vaccine cannot solve global underinvestment in essential public health functions and resilient health systems, nor the urgent need for an approach that encompasses humans, animals and the planet we share," said the director. Tedros also indicated that 186 countries are already participating in the Covax initiative for the distribution of vaccines. coronavirus prevention.

Joe Biden stressed that, even if the immunizer is approved, people will have to continue depending on the use of MASKS, SOCIAL DISTANCE and other measures to ensure security.

<font color="#EC7063">Masks and Social Distance. The reality even for the coming months </font>

Wearing MASKS and  Social Distance. "This is the reality for now and for the coming months," 
https://translate.google.com.br/translate?hl=en&sl=pt&u=https://epocanegocios.globo.com/Mundo/noticia/2020/11/epoca-negocios-oms-tedros-adhanom-afirma-que-vacina-nao-resolvera-vulnerabilidades.html&prev=search&pto=aue
source.f500fe4e: ### Connecting Culture and The Romantic Disease: TUBERCULOSIS Interweaving the culture and science of tuberculosis Author: Colin Martin - Published:February 27, 2014DOI:https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(14)60392-5 Tuberculosis has inspired poets, novelists, composers, and artists for centuries. Its hold on human creativity seems as tenacious as its persistent and devastating grip on global health. TB was fashionable in certain creative circles during the early 19th century. The Romantic poet Lord Byron remarked to Thomas Moore, his eventual biographer: “I should like to die of a consumption…because the ladies would all say ‘Look at that poor Byron, how interesting he looks in dying!’” Gram-staining bacteria Process is similar to art techniques Paul Ehrlich observed that animal cell membranes and bacterial cell walls had differing affinities for dyes and proposed that it should be possible to develop chemicals that would kill pathogenic bacteria without harming host animals or humans. “The process of Gram-staining bacteria is similar to art techniques such as etching” https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(14)60392-5/fulltext An Artistic Investigation of Tuberculosis “The Romantic Disease: An Artistic Investigation of Tuberculosis”, is a brand new solo exhibition by Anna Dumitriu showing installations and sculptures made with strains of mycobacteria, transformed historical artefacts, and textiles that our reveal the complexities of Tuberculosis (TB) and our responses to the disease. The show explores the strange history of TB from artistic, social and scientific perspectives and covers subjects such as superstitions about the disease, its literary and romantic associations, the development of antibiotics and the latest research into whole genome sequencing of bacteria. https://www.watermans.org.uk/new-media-arts-archive/the-romantic-disease-an-artistic-investigation-of-tuberculosis/
